text:
*[Bug 14825] Possibility to set srcref when evaluating an expr (of any kind)*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=14825>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED
             Status|NEW                         |CLOSED

--- Comment #4 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
For reference, this has been addressed 3 months after the report. Since then
source references are maintained when evaluating an EXPRSXP, using code similar
to the proposed patch. As in the proposed patch, the source references are
taken from a block.

As already answered above, the idea of attaching a corresponding attribute to
every single expression directly wouldn't work with how R is designed, because
some of these expressions are represented by objects shared among different
pieces of code. In other words, that would be too expensive.

elements.text: [Bug 14825] Possibility to set srcref when evaluating an expr (of any kind)

) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED
             Status|NEW                         |CLOSED

--- Comment #4 from Tomas Kalibera (

) ---
For reference, this has been addressed 3 months after the report. Since then
source references are maintained when evaluating an EXPRSXP, using code similar
to the proposed patch. As in the proposed patch, the source references are
taken from a block.

As already answered above, the idea of attaching a corresponding attribute to
every single expression directly wouldn't work with how R is designed, because
some of these expressions are represented by objects shared among different
pieces of code. In other words, that would be too expensive.

text:
*[Bug 16632] Using -Wl,-bexpall causes many duplicate symbol warnings*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16632>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Thanks for the report.

For reference, baseRegisterIndex has been fixed (missing "extern" added) by now
(also PR#17385). The multiple definitions of bison-generated symbols for
parsers were fixed by their renaming in the tools package in 2019. 

Rf_dpptr has been probably by accident defined both in base R and in graphics
package. It is not used in base R, so I've now removed the definition from
there.

elements.text: [Bug 16632] Using -Wl,-bexpall causes many duplicate symbol warnings

) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (

) ---
Thanks for the report.

For reference, baseRegisterIndex has been fixed (missing "extern" added) by now
(also PR#17385). The multiple definitions of bison-generated symbols for
parsers were fixed by their renaming in the tools package in 2019. 

Rf_dpptr has been probably by accident defined both in base R and in graphics
package. It is not used in base R, so I've now removed the definition from
there.

text:
*[Bug 18864] R-4.4.3 fails to build utils.dll due to missing "-lzma" on Cygwin*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18864>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
         Resolution|---                         |WONTFIX
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #3 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Thanks for the context. I can describe the testing done for the supported
Windows/mingw-w64 target. CRAN checks all contributed packages for the current
development version of R and the two last releases, on any package change. For
non-trivial changes to the development version of R, the R core team often
checks against all CRAN and sometimes Bioconductor packages. Any Rtools update
(the gcc/mingw-w64 toolchain used to build R and packages) involves also
testing on all CRAN and most or all Bioconductor packages before release.

All of this requires a lot of resources. The goal is to provide one build for
Windows R users that works well. We unfortunately do not have any resources
left to maintain R for Cygwin. The R Installation and Administration Manual
says that Cygwin is not supported, see
<https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/R-admin.html#Cygwin>.

elements.text: [Bug 18864] R-4.4.3 fails to build utils.dll due to missing "-lzma" on Cygwin

) changed:

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
         Resolution|---                         |WONTFIX
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

text:
*[Bug 18932] ?options could be clearer that R_INTERACTIVE_DEVICE,R_DEFAULT_DEVICE only support strings*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18932>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I don't think this is necessary, it should be obvious from the documentation
and the documentation shouldn't be expanded unnecessarily in the interest of
readability.

The documentation says that "device" is "a character string giving the name of
a function, or the function object itself". An environment variable always
contains a string - how could it possibly contain a function object?

Setting

R_DEFAULT_DEVICE="function(...) pdf(file=NULL)";

still sets the variable to a string, hence will be interpreted as a function
name.

elements.text: [Bug 18932] ?options could be clearer that R_INTERACTIVE_DEVICE,R_DEFAULT_DEVICE only support strings

) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (

) ---

readability.

contains a string - how could it possibly contain a function object?

Setting

still sets the variable to a string, hence will be interpreted as a function
name.

text:
*[Bug 17807] parRapply and parCapply return a list instead of a (numeric) vector when function returns vectors of different lengths*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17807>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #6 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Thanks for the report. I agree this is a bug, from my reading of the
documentation, the result should be an atomic vector, not a generic vector,
even when the workers return result atomic vectors of different lengths and the
number of workers doesn't match the number of rows (or columns) in the input
for parRapply() (or parCapply()). Also, as long as such input and behavior of
workers is allowed, which I believe it is, the current behavior is undesirable,
because one gets different result structure depending on (undocumented)
properties of the inputs/workers.

The problem is caused by the use of the default "simplify=TRUE" in the
underlying "apply" used by parRapply()/parCapply(). The simplification in some
cases, like the one reported here, wouldn't get rid of the list. I've changed
the implementation to use apply(simplify=FALSE) and then twice non-recursive
unlist(), now in R-devel. I've tested on CRAN and Bioconductor packages and 
didn't find any package depending on the old behavior.

elements.text: [Bug 17807] parRapply and parCapply return a list instead of a (numeric) vector when function returns vectors of different lengths

) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #6 from Tomas Kalibera (

) ---
Thanks for the report. I agree this is a bug, from my reading of the
documentation, the result should be an atomic vector, not a generic vector,
even when the workers return result atomic vectors of different lengths and the
number of workers doesn't match the number of rows (or columns) in the input
for parRapply() (or parCapply()). Also, as long as such input and behavior of
workers is allowed, which I believe it is, the current behavior is undesirable,
because one gets different result structure depending on (undocumented)
properties of the inputs/workers.

The problem is caused by the use of the default "simplify=TRUE" in the
underlying "apply" used by parRapply()/parCapply(). The simplification in some
cases, like the one reported here, wouldn't get rid of the list. I've changed
the implementation to use apply(simplify=FALSE) and then twice non-recursive
unlist(), now in R-devel. I've tested on CRAN and Bioconductor packages and 
didn't find any package depending on the old behavior.
